docs.text: image/svg+xml The Ibis Project ¶ The flexibility of Python analytics with the scale and performance of modern SQL. ¶ Install Tutorial Write high-level Python code >>> import ibis >>> con = ibis . connect ( 'movielens.sqlite' ) >>> movies = con . tables . movies >>> rating_by_year = movies . group_by ( 'year' ) . avg_rating . mean () >>> q = rating_by_year . order_by ( rating_by_year . year . desc ()) Compile to SQL >>> con . compile ( q ) SELECT year , avg ( avg_rating ) FROM movies t1 GROUP BY t1 . year ORDER BY t1 . year DESC Execute on multiple backends >>> con . execute ( q ) year mean ( avg_rating ) 0 2021 2.586362 1 2020 2.719994 2 2019 2.932275 3 2018 3.005046 4 2017 3.071669 Features ¶ Consistent syntax across backends : Enjoy a uniform Python API, whether using DuckDB , PostgreSQL , PySpark , BigQuery , or any other supported backend . Performant : Execute queries as fast as the database engine itself. Interactive : Explore data in a notebook or REPL. Extensible : Add new operations, optimizations, and custom APIs. Free and open-source : licensed under Apache 2.0, available on Github

--jp-border-color2: var(--md-grey-300); --jp-border-color3: var(--md-grey-200); --jp-border-radius: 2px; /* UI Fonts * * The UI font CSS variables are used for the typography all of the JupyterLab * user interface elements that are not directly user generated content. * * The font sizing here is done assuming that the body font size of --jp-ui-font-size1 * is applied to a parent element. When children elements, such as headings, are sized * in em all things will be computed relative to that body size. */ --jp-ui-font-scale-factor: 1.2; --jp-ui-font-size0: 0.83333em; --jp-ui-font-size1: 13px; /* Base font size */ --jp-ui-font-size2: 1.2em; --jp-ui-font-size3: 1.44em; --jp-ui-font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, "Segoe UI", Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif, "Apple Color Emoji", "Segoe UI Emoji", "Segoe UI Symbol"; /* * Use these font colors against the corresponding main layout colors. * In a light theme, these go from dark to light. */ /* Defaults use Material Design specification */ --jp-ui-font-color0: rgba(0, 0, 0, 1); --jp-ui-font-color1: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.87); --jp-ui-font-color2: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.54); --jp-ui-font-color3: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.38); /* * Use these against the brand/accent/warn/error colors. * These will typically go from light to darker, in both a dark and light theme. */ --jp-ui-inverse-font-color0: rgba(255, 255, 255, 1); --jp-ui-inverse-font-color1: rgba(255, 255, 255, 1); --jp-ui-inverse-font-color2: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.7); --jp-ui-inverse-font-color3: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.5); /* Content Fonts * * Content font variables are used for typography of user generated content. * * The font sizing here is done assuming that the body font size of --jp-content-font-size1 * is applied to a parent element. tex2jax: { inlineMath: [ ['$','$'], ["\\(","\\)"] ], displayMath: [ ['$$','$$'], ["\\[","\\]"] ], processEscapes: true, processEnvironments: true }, displayAlign: 'center', CommonHTML: { linebreaks: { automatic: true } } }); MathJax.Hub.Queue(["Typeset", MathJax.Hub]); } } init_mathjax(); Ibis for pandas Users ¶ Much of the syntax and many of the operations in Ibis are inspired by the pandas DataFrame, however, the primary domain of Ibis is SQL so there are some differences in how they operate. One primary difference between Ibis tables and pandas DataFrame s are that many of the pandas DataFrame operations do in-place operations (they are "mutable"), whereas Ibis table operations always return a new table expression ("immutable"). Another difference is that Ibis expressions are lazy, meaning that as you build up an expression, no computation is actually performed until you call an action method such as execute . Only then does Ibis compile the expression into SQL and send it to the backend. (Note that we'll be using Ibis' interactive mode to automatically execute queries at the end of each cell in this notebook. If you are using similar code in a program, you will have to add .execute() to each operation that you want to evaluate.) In [1]: Copied! import ibis import pandas as pd ibis . options . interactive = True import ibis import pandas as pd ibis.options.interactive = True We'll be using the pandas backend in Ibis in the examples below. First we'll create a simple DataFrame . In [2]: Copied! df = pd . DataFrame ( [ [ 'a' , 1 , 2 ], [ 'b' , 3 , 4 ] ], columns = [ 'one' , 'two' , 'three' ], index = [ 5 , 6 ], ) df df = pd.DataFrame( [ ['a', 1, 2], ['b', 3, 4] ], columns=['one', 'two', 'three'], index=[5,6], ) df Out[2]: .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type { vertical-align: middle; } .dataframe tbody tr th { vertical-align: top; } .dataframe thead th { text-align: right; } one two three 5 a 1 2 6 b 3 4 Now we can create an Ibis table from the above DataFrame . Note that the index from the Pandas DataFrame is dropped. Ibis has no notion of an index: If you want to use the index, you will need to turn it into a column. In [3]: Copied! t = ibis . pandas . connect ({ 't' : df }) . table ( 't' ) t t = ibis.pandas.connect({'t': df}).table('t') t Out[3]: ┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓ ┃ one ┃ two ┃ three ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ int64 │ ├────────┼───────┼───────┤ │ a │ 1 │ 2 │ │ b │ 3 │ 4 │ └────────┴───────┴───────┘ Data types ¶ The data types of columns in pandas are accessed using the dtypes attribute. This returns a Series object. In [4]: Copied! df . dtypes df.dtypes Out[4]: one object two int64 three int64 dtype: object In Ibis, you use the schema method which returns an ibis.Schema object. In [5]: Copied! t . schema () t.schema() Out[5]: ibis.Schema { one string two int64 three int64 } It is possible to convert the schema information to pandas data types using the to_pandas method, if needed. In [6]: Copied! t . schema () . to_pandas () t.schema().to_pandas() Out[6]: [('one', dtype('O')), ('two', dtype('int64')), ('three', dtype('int64'))] Table layout ¶ In pandas, the layout of the table is contained in the shape attribute which contains the number of rows and number of columns in a tuple. The number of columns in an Ibis table can be gotten from the length of the schema. In [7]: Copied! len ( t . schema ()) len(t.schema()) Out[7]: 3 To get the number of rows of a table, you use the count method. In [8]: Copied! t . count () t.count() Out[8]: 2 To mimic pandas' behavior, you would use the following code. Note that you need to use the execute method after count to evaluate the expression returned by count . In [9]: Copied! ( t . count () . execute (), len ( t . schema ())) (t.count().execute(), len(t.schema())) Out[9]: (2, 3) In [10]: Copied! df . shape df.shape Out[10]: (2, 3) Subsetting columns ¶ Selecting columns is very similar to in pandas. In fact, you can use the same syntax. In [11]: Copied! t [[ 'one' , 'two' ]] t[['one', 'two']] Out[11]: ┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓ ┃ one ┃ two ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ ├────────┼───────┤ │ a │ 1 │ │ b │ 3 │ └────────┴───────┘ However, since row-level indexing is not supported in Ibis, the inner list is not necessary. In [12]: Copied! t [ 'one' , 'two' ] t['one', 'two'] Out[12]: ┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓ ┃ one ┃ two ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ ├────────┼───────┤ │ a │ 1 │ │ b │ 3 │ └────────┴───────┘ Selecting columns ¶ Selecting columns is done using the same syntax as in pandas DataFrames . You can use either the indexing syntax or attribute syntax. In [13]: Copied! t [ 'one' ] t['one'] Out[13]: ┏━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ one ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ ├────────┤ │ a │ │ b │ └────────┘ or: In [14]: Copied! t . one t.one Out[14]: ┏━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ one ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ ├────────┤ │ a │ │ b │ └────────┘ Adding, removing, and modifying columns ¶ Modifying the columns of an Ibis table is a bit different than doing the same operations in a pandas DataFrame . This is primarily due to the fact that in-place operations are not supported on Ibis tables. Each time you do a column modification to a table, a new table expression is returned. Adding columns ¶ Adding columns is done through the mutate method. In [15]: Copied! mutated = t . mutate ( new_col = t . three * 2 ) mutated mutated = t.mutate(new_col=t.three * 2) mutated Out[15]: ┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ one ┃ two ┃ three ┃ new_col ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ int64 │ int64 │ ├────────┼───────┼───────┼─────────┤ │ a │ 1 │ 2 │ 4 │ │ b │ 3 │ 4 │ 8 │ └────────┴───────┴───────┴─────────┘ Notice that the original table object remains unchanged. Only the mutated object that was returned contains the new column. In [16]: Copied! t t Out[16]: ┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓ ┃ one ┃ two ┃ three ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ int64 │ ├────────┼───────┼───────┤ │ a │ 1 │ 2 │ │ b │ 3 │ 4 │ └────────┴───────┴───────┘ It is also possible to create a column in isolation. This is similar to a Series in pandas. Note that the name of the column by default is a representation of the expression: In [17]: Copied! unnamed = ( t . three * 2 ) unnamed unnamed = (t.three * 2) unnamed Out[17]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ Multiply(three, 2) ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩ │ int64 │ ├────────────────────┤ │ 4 │ │ 8 │ └────────────────────┘ To get a version with a specific name, you can use the name method: In [18]: Copied! new_col = unnamed . name ( "new_col" ) new_col new_col = unnamed.name("new_col") new_col Out[18]: ┏━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ new_col ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━┩ │ int64 │ ├─────────┤ │ 4 │ │ 8 │ └─────────┘ You can then add this column to the table using a projection. In [19]: Copied! proj = t [ 'one' , 'two' , new_col ] proj proj = t['one', 'two', new_col] proj Out[19]: ┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ one ┃ two ┃ new_col ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ int64 │ ├────────┼───────┼─────────┤ │ a │ 1 │ 4 │ │ b │ 3 │ 8 │ └────────┴───────┴─────────┘ Removing columns ¶ Removing a column is done using the drop method. In [20]: Copied! t . columns t.columns Out[20]: ['one', 'two', 'three'] In [21]: Copied! subset = t . drop ( 'one' , 'two' ) subset . columns subset = t.drop('one', 'two') subset.columns Out[21]: ['three'] It is also possible to drop columns by selecting the columns you want to remain. In [22]: Copied! subset = t [ 'two' , 'three' ] subset . columns subset = t['two', 'three'] subset.columns Out[22]: ['two', 'three'] Modifying columns ¶ Replacing existing columns is done using the mutate method just like adding columns. You simply add a column of the same name to replace it. In [23]: Copied! t t Out[23]: ┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓ ┃ one ┃ two ┃ three ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ int64 │ ├────────┼───────┼───────┤ │ a │ 1 │ 2 │ │ b │ 3 │ 4 │ └────────┴───────┴───────┘ In [24]: Copied! mutated = t . mutate ( two = t . two * 2 ) mutated mutated = t.mutate(two=t.two * 2) mutated Out[24]: ┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓ ┃ one ┃ two ┃ three ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ int64 │ ├────────┼───────┼───────┤ │ a │ 2 │ 2 │ │ b │ 6 │ 4 │ └────────┴───────┴───────┘ Renaming columns ¶ In addition to replacing columns, you can simply rename them as well. This is done with the relabel method which takes a dictionary containing the name mappings. In [25]: Copied! relabeled = t . relabel ( dict ( one = 'a' , two = 'b' , )) relabeled relabeled = t.relabel(dict( one='a', two='b', )) relabeled Out[25]: ┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓ ┃ a ┃ b ┃ three ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ int64 │ ├────────┼───────┼───────┤ │ a │ 1 │ 2 │ │ b │ 3 │ 4 │ └────────┴───────┴───────┘ Selecting rows ¶ There are several methods that can be used to select rows of data in various ways. These are described in the sections below. We'll use the ubiquitous iris dataset for these examples. In [26]: Copied! df = pd . read_csv ( 'https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mwaskom/seaborn-data/master/iris.csv' ) df . head () df = pd.read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mwaskom/seaborn-data/master/iris.csv') df.head() Out[26]: .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type { vertical-align: middle; } .dataframe tbody tr th { vertical-align: top; } .dataframe thead th { text-align: right; } sepal_length sepal_width petal_length petal_width species 0 5.1 3.5 1.4 0.2 setosa 1 4.9 3.0 1.4 0.2 setosa 2 4.7 3.2 1.3 0.2 setosa 3 4.6 3.1 1.5 0.2 setosa 4 5.0 3.6 1.4 0.2 setosa Create an Ibis table from the DataFrame above. In [27]: Copied! t = ibis . pandas . connect ({ 't' : df }) . table ( 't' ) t t = ibis.pandas.connect({'t': df}).table('t') t Out[27]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ sepal_length ┃ sepal_width ┃ petal_length ┃ petal_width ┃ species ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ string │ ├──────────────┼─────────────┼──────────────┼─────────────┼─────────┤ │ 5.1 │ 3.5 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.9 │ 3.0 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.7 │ 3.2 │ 1.3 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.6 │ 3.1 │ 1.5 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 5.0 │ 3.6 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 5.4 │ 3.9 │ 1.7 │ 0.4 │ setosa │ │ 4.6 │ 3.4 │ 1.4 │ 0.3 │ setosa │ │ 5.0 │ 3.4 │ 1.5 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.4 │ 2.9 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.9 │ 3.1 │ 1.5 │ 0.1 │ setosa │ │ … │ … │ … │ … │ … │ └──────────────┴─────────────┴──────────────┴─────────────┴─────────┘ Head, tail and limit ¶ The head method works the same ways as in pandas. Note that some Ibis backends may not have an inherent ordering of their rows and using head may not return deterministic results. In those cases, you can use sorting before calling head to ensure a stable result. In [28]: Copied! t . head ( 5 ) t.head(5) Out[28]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ sepal_length ┃ sepal_width ┃ petal_length ┃ petal_width ┃ species ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ string │ ├──────────────┼─────────────┼──────────────┼─────────────┼─────────┤ │ 5.1 │ 3.5 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.9 │ 3.0 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.7 │ 3.2 │ 1.3 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.6 │ 3.1 │ 1.5 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 5.0 │ 3.6 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ └──────────────┴─────────────┴──────────────┴─────────────┴─────────┘ However, the tail method is not implemented since it is not supported in all databases. It is possible to emulate the tail method if you use sorting in your table to do a reverse sort then use the head method to retrieve the "top" rows. Another way to limit the number of retrieved rows is using the limit method. The following will return the same result as head(5) . This is often used in conjunction with other filtering techniques that we will cover later. In [29]: Copied! t . limit ( 5 ) t.limit(5) Out[29]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ sepal_length ┃ sepal_width ┃ petal_length ┃ petal_width ┃ species ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ string │ ├──────────────┼─────────────┼──────────────┼─────────────┼─────────┤ │ 5.1 │ 3.5 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.9 │ 3.0 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.7 │ 3.2 │ 1.3 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.6 │ 3.1 │ 1.5 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 5.0 │ 3.6 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ └──────────────┴─────────────┴──────────────┴─────────────┴─────────┘ The starting position of the returned rows can be specified using the offset parameter. In [30]: Copied! t . limit ( 5 , offset = 4 ) t.limit(5, offset=4) Out[30]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ sepal_length ┃ sepal_width ┃ petal_length ┃ petal_width ┃ species ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ string │ ├──────────────┼─────────────┼──────────────┼─────────────┼─────────┤ │ 5.0 │ 3.6 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 5.4 │ 3.9 │ 1.7 │ 0.4 │ setosa │ │ 4.6 │ 3.4 │ 1.4 │ 0.3 │ setosa │ │ 5.0 │ 3.4 │ 1.5 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.4 │ 2.9 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ └──────────────┴─────────────┴──────────────┴─────────────┴─────────┘ Filtering rows ¶ In addition to simply limiting the number of rows that are returned, it is possible to filter the rows using expressions. Expressions are constructed very similarly to the way they are in pandas. Ibis expressions are constructed from operations on colunms in a table which return a boolean result. This result is then used to filter the table. In [31]: Copied! expr = t . sepal_width > 3.8 expr expr = t.sepal_width > 3.8 expr Out[31]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ Greater(sepal_width, 3.8) ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩ │ boolean │ ├───────────────────────────┤ │ False │ │ False │ │ False │ │ False │ │ False │ │ True │ │ False │ │ False │ │ False │ │ False │ │ … │ └───────────────────────────┘ We can evaluate the value counts to see how many rows we will expect to get back after filtering. In [32]: Copied! expr . value_counts () expr.value_counts() Out[32]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ Greater(sepal_width, 3.8) ┃ Greater(sepal_width, 3.8)_count ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩ │ boolean │ int64 │ ├───────────────────────────┼─────────────────────────────────┤ │ False │ 144 │ │ True │ 6 │ └───────────────────────────┴─────────────────────────────────┘ Now we apply the filter to the table. Since there are 6 True values in the expression, we should get 6 rows back. In [33]: Copied! filtered = t [ expr ] filtered filtered = t[expr] filtered Out[33]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ sepal_length ┃ sepal_width ┃ petal_length ┃ petal_width ┃ species ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ string │ ├──────────────┼─────────────┼──────────────┼─────────────┼─────────┤ │ 5.4 │ 3.9 │ 1.7 │ 0.4 │ setosa │ │ 5.8 │ 4.0 │ 1.2 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 5.7 │ 4.4 │ 1.5 │ 0.4 │ setosa │ │ 5.4 │ 3.9 │ 1.3 │ 0.4 │ setosa │ │ 5.2 │ 4.1 │ 1.5 │ 0.1 │ setosa │ │ 5.5 │ 4.2 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ └──────────────┴─────────────┴──────────────┴─────────────┴─────────┘ Of course, the filtering expression can be applied inline as well. In [34]: Copied! filtered = t [ t . sepal_width > 3.8 ] filtered filtered = t[t.sepal_width > 3.8] filtered Out[34]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ sepal_length ┃ sepal_width ┃ petal_length ┃ petal_width ┃ species ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ string │ ├──────────────┼─────────────┼──────────────┼─────────────┼─────────┤ │ 5.4 │ 3.9 │ 1.7 │ 0.4 │ setosa │ │ 5.8 │ 4.0 │ 1.2 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 5.7 │ 4.4 │ 1.5 │ 0.4 │ setosa │ │ 5.4 │ 3.9 │ 1.3 │ 0.4 │ setosa │ │ 5.2 │ 4.1 │ 1.5 │ 0.1 │ setosa │ │ 5.5 │ 4.2 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ └──────────────┴─────────────┴──────────────┴─────────────┴─────────┘ Multiple filtering expressions can be combined into a single expression or chained onto existing table expressions. In [35]: Copied! filtered = t [( t . sepal_width > 3.8 ) & ( t . sepal_length > 5.5 )] filtered filtered = t[(t.sepal_width > 3.8) & (t.sepal_length > 5.5)] filtered Out[35]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ sepal_length ┃ sepal_width ┃ petal_length ┃ petal_width ┃ species ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ string │ ├──────────────┼─────────────┼──────────────┼─────────────┼─────────┤ │ 5.8 │ 4.0 │ 1.2 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 5.7 │ 4.4 │ 1.5 │ 0.4 │ setosa │ └──────────────┴─────────────┴──────────────┴─────────────┴─────────┘ The code above will return the same rows as the code below. In [36]: Copied! filtered = t [ t . sepal_width > 3.8 ][ t . sepal_length > 5.5 ] filtered filtered = t[t.sepal_width > 3.8][t.sepal_length > 5.5] filtered Out[36]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ sepal_length ┃ sepal_width ┃ petal_length ┃ petal_width ┃ species ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ string │ ├──────────────┼─────────────┼──────────────┼─────────────┼─────────┤ │ 5.8 │ 4.0 │ 1.2 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 5.7 │ 4.4 │ 1.5 │ 0.4 │ setosa │ └──────────────┴─────────────┴──────────────┴─────────────┴─────────┘ Aggregation has not been discussed yet, but aggregate values can be used in expressions to return things such as all of the rows in a data set where the value in a column is greater than the mean. In [37]: Copied! filtered = t [ t . sepal_width > t . sepal_width . mean ()] filtered filtered = t[t.sepal_width > t.sepal_width.mean()] filtered Out[37]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ sepal_length ┃ sepal_width ┃ petal_length ┃ petal_width ┃ species ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ string │ ├──────────────┼─────────────┼──────────────┼─────────────┼─────────┤ │ 5.1 │ 3.5 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.7 │ 3.2 │ 1.3 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.6 │ 3.1 │ 1.5 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 5.0 │ 3.6 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 5.4 │ 3.9 │ 1.7 │ 0.4 │ setosa │ │ 4.6 │ 3.4 │ 1.4 │ 0.3 │ setosa │ │ 5.0 │ 3.4 │ 1.5 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.9 │ 3.1 │ 1.5 │ 0.1 │ setosa │ │ 5.4 │ 3.7 │ 1.5 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.8 │ 3.4 │ 1.6 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ … │ … │ … │ … │ … │ └──────────────┴─────────────┴──────────────┴─────────────┴─────────┘ Modifying rows ¶ Sometimes you want to modify the values in a column based on some condition. In pandas, you would do something like df.loc[condition] = new_value . In Ibis though, remember that all expressions are immutable, so you need to create a new table expression with the modified values. You do this using the ifelse method on boolean columns: In [38]: Copied! wide_sepals = t . sepal_width > 3.3 species_modified = wide_sepals . ifelse ( 'wide' , t . species ) t . mutate ( species_modified = species_modified ) wide_sepals = t.sepal_width > 3.3 species_modified = wide_sepals.ifelse('wide', t.species) t.mutate(species_modified=species_modified) Out[38]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ sepal_length ┃ sepal_width ┃ petal_length ┃ petal_width ┃ species ┃ species_modified ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ string │ string │ ├──────────────┼─────────────┼──────────────┼─────────────┼─────────┼──────────────────┤ │ 5.1 │ 3.5 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ wide │ │ 4.9 │ 3.0 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ setosa │ │ 4.7 │ 3.2 │ 1.3 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ setosa │ │ 4.6 │ 3.1 │ 1.5 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ setosa │ │ 5.0 │ 3.6 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ wide │ │ 5.4 │ 3.9 │ 1.7 │ 0.4 │ setosa │ wide │ │ 4.6 │ 3.4 │ 1.4 │ 0.3 │ setosa │ wide │ │ 5.0 │ 3.4 │ 1.5 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ wide │ │ 4.4 │ 2.9 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ setosa │ │ 4.9 │ 3.1 │ 1.5 │ 0.1 │ setosa │ setosa │ │ … │ … │ … │ … │ … │ … │ └──────────────┴─────────────┴──────────────┴─────────────┴─────────┴──────────────────┘ Sorting rows ¶ Sorting rows in Ibis uses a somewhat different API than in pandas. In pandas, you would use the sort_values method to order rows by values in specified columns. Ibis uses a method called order_by . To specify ascending or descending orders, pandas uses an ascending= argument to sort_values that indicates the order for each sorting column. Ibis allows you to tag the column name in the order_by list as ascending or descending by wrapping it with ibis.asc or ibis.desc . Here is an example of sorting a DataFrame using two sort keys. One key is sorting in ascending order and the other is in descending order. In [39]: Copied! df . sort_values ([ 'sepal_length' , 'sepal_width' ], ascending = [ True , False ]) . head ( 5 ) df.sort_values(['sepal_length', 'sepal_width'], ascending=[True, False]).head(5) Out[39]: .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type { vertical-align: middle; } .dataframe tbody tr th { vertical-align: top; } .dataframe thead th { text-align: right; } sepal_length sepal_width petal_length petal_width species 13 4.3 3.0 1.1 0.1 setosa 42 4.4 3.2 1.3 0.2 setosa 38 4.4 3.0 1.3 0.2 setosa 8 4.4 2.9 1.4 0.2 setosa 41 4.5 2.3 1.3 0.3 setosa The same operation in Ibis would look like the following. Note that the index values of the resulting DataFrame start from zero and count up, whereas in the example above, they retain their original index value. This is simply due to the fact that rows in tables don't necessarily have a stable index in database backends, so the index is just generated on the result. In [40]: Copied! sorted = t . order_by ([ 'sepal_length' , ibis . desc ( 'sepal_width' )]) . head ( 5 ) sorted sorted = t.order_by(['sepal_length', ibis.desc('sepal_width')]).head(5) sorted Out[40]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ sepal_length ┃ sepal_width ┃ petal_length ┃ petal_width ┃ species ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ string │ ├──────────────┼─────────────┼──────────────┼─────────────┼─────────┤ │ 4.3 │ 3.0 │ 1.1 │ 0.1 │ setosa │ │ 4.4 │ 3.2 │ 1.3 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.4 │ 3.0 │ 1.3 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.4 │ 2.9 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.5 │ 2.3 │ 1.3 │ 0.3 │ setosa │ └──────────────┴─────────────┴──────────────┴─────────────┴─────────┘ Aggregation ¶ Aggregation in pandas is typically done by computing columns based on an aggregate function. In [41]: Copied! stats = [ df . sepal_width . sum (), df . sepal_length . mean ()] pd . DataFrame ([ stats ], columns = [ 'total_sepal_width' , 'avg.sepal_length' ]) stats = [df.sepal_width.sum(), df.sepal_length.mean()] pd.DataFrame([stats], columns=['total_sepal_width', 'avg.sepal_length']) Out[41]: .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type { vertical-align: middle; } .dataframe tbody tr th { vertical-align: top; } .dataframe thead th { text-align: right; } total_sepal_width avg.sepal_length 0 458.6 5.843333 In Ibis, you construct aggregate expressions then apply them to the table using the aggregate method. In [42]: Copied! stats = [ t . sepal_width . sum () . name ( 'total_sepal_width' ), t . sepal_length . mean () . name ( 'avg_sepal_length' )] agged = t . aggregate ( stats ) agged stats = [t.sepal_width.sum().name('total_sepal_width'), t.sepal_length.mean().name('avg_sepal_length')] agged = t.aggregate(stats) agged Out[42]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ total_sepal_width ┃ avg_sepal_length ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ ├───────────────────┼──────────────────┤ │ 458.6 │ 5.843333 │ └───────────────────┴──────────────────┘ You can also combine both operations into one and pass the aggregate expressions using keyword parameters. In [43]: Copied! agged = t . aggregate ( total_sepal_width = t . sepal_width . sum (), avg_sepal_length = t . sepal_length . mean (), ) agged agged = t.aggregate( total_sepal_width=t.sepal_width.sum(), avg_sepal_length=t.sepal_length.mean(), ) agged Out[43]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ total_sepal_width ┃ avg_sepal_length ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ ├───────────────────┼──────────────────┤ │ 458.6 │ 5.843333 │ └───────────────────┴──────────────────┘ Group by ¶ Aggregations can also be done across groupings using the by= parameter. In [44]: Copied! agged = t . aggregate ( by = 'species' , total_sepal_width = t . sepal_width . sum (), avg_sepal_length = t . sepal_length . mean (), ) agged agged = t.aggregate( by='species', total_sepal_width=t.sepal_width.sum(), avg_sepal_length=t.sepal_length.mean(), ) agged Out[44]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ species ┃ total_sepal_width ┃ avg_sepal_length ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ float64 │ float64 │ ├────────────┼───────────────────┼──────────────────┤ │ setosa │ 171.4 │ 5.006 │ │ versicolor │ 138.5 │ 5.936 │ │ virginica │ 148.7 │ 6.588 │ └────────────┴───────────────────┴──────────────────┘ Alternatively, by groups can be computed using a grouped table. In [45]: Copied! agged = t . group_by ( 'species' ) . aggregate ( total_sepal_width = t . sepal_width . sum (), avg_sepal_length = t . sepal_length . mean (), ) agged agged = t.group_by('species').aggregate( total_sepal_width=t.sepal_width.sum(), avg_sepal_length=t.sepal_length.mean(), ) agged Out[45]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ species ┃ total_sepal_width ┃ avg_sepal_length ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ float64 │ float64 │ ├────────────┼───────────────────┼──────────────────┤ │ setosa │ 171.4 │ 5.006 │ │ versicolor │ 138.5 │ 5.936 │ │ virginica │ 148.7 │ 6.588 │ └────────────┴───────────────────┴──────────────────┘ Dropping rows with NULL s ¶ Both pandas and Ibis allow you to drop rows from a table based on whether a set of columns contains a NULL value. This method is called dropna in both packages. The common set of parameters in the two are subset= and how= . The subset= parameter indicates which columns to inspect for NULL values. The how= parameter specifies whether 'any' or 'all' of the specified columns must be NULL in order for the row to be dropped. In [46]: Copied! no_null_t = t . dropna ([ 'sepal_width' , 'sepal_length' ], how = 'any' ) no_null_t = t.dropna(['sepal_width', 'sepal_length'], how='any') Filling NULL values ¶ Both pandas and Ibis allow you to fill NULL values in a table. In Ibis, the replacement value can only be a scalar value of a dictionary of values. If it is a dictionary, the keys of the dictionary specify the column name for the value to apply to. In [47]: Copied! no_null_t = t . fillna ( dict ( sepal_width = 0 , sepal_length = 0 )) no_null_t = t.fillna(dict(sepal_width=0, sepal_length=0)) Common column expressions ¶ See the full API documentation for all of the available value methods and tools for creating value expressions. We mention a few common ones here as they relate to common SQL queries. Type casts ¶ Type casting in pandas is done using the astype method on columns. In [48]: Copied! df . sepal_width . astype ( str ) df.sepal_width.astype(str) Out[48]: 0 3.5 1 3.0 2 3.2 3 3.1 4 3.6 ... 145 3.0 146 2.5 147 3.0 148 3.4 149 3.0 Name: sepal_width, Length: 150, dtype: object In Ibis, you cast the column type using the cast method. In [49]: Copied! t . sepal_width . cast ( 'int' ) t.sepal_width.cast('int') Out[49]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ Cast(sepal_width, int64) ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩ │ int64 │ ├──────────────────────────┤ │ 3 │ │ 3 │ │ 3 │ │ 3 │ │ 3 │ │ 3 │ │ 3 │ │ 3 │ │ 2 │ │ 3 │ │ … │ └──────────────────────────┘ Casted columns can be assigned back to the table using the mutate method described earlier. In [50]: Copied! casted = t . mutate ( sepal_width = t . sepal_width . cast ( 'int' ), sepal_length = t . sepal_length . cast ( 'int' ), ) casted . schema () casted = t.mutate( sepal_width=t.sepal_width.cast('int'), sepal_length=t.sepal_length.cast('int'), ) casted.schema() Out[50]: ibis.Schema { sepal_length int64 sepal_width int64 petal_length float64 petal_width float64 species string } Replacing NULL s ¶ Both pandas and Ibis have fillna methods which allow you to specify a replacement value for NULL values. In [51]: Copied! sepal_length_no_nulls = t . sepal_length . fillna ( 0 ) sepal_length_no_nulls = t.sepal_length.fillna(0) Set membership ¶ pandas set membership uses the in and not in operators such as 'a' in df.species . Ibis uses isin and notin methods. In addition to testing membership in a set, these methods allow you to specify an else case to assign a value when the value isn't in the set. In [52]: Copied! t . species . value_counts () t.species.value_counts() Out[52]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ species ┃ species_count ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ ├────────────┼───────────────┤ │ setosa │ 50 │ │ versicolor │ 50 │ │ virginica │ 50 │ └────────────┴───────────────┘ In [53]: Copied! refined = t . species . isin ([ 'versicolor' , 'virginica' ]) refined . value_counts () refined = t.species.isin(['versicolor', 'virginica']) refined.value_counts() Out[53]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ Contains(species) ┃ Contains(species)_count ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩ │ boolean │ int64 │ ├───────────────────┼─────────────────────────┤ │ False │ 50 │ │ True │ 100 │ └───────────────────┴─────────────────────────┘ Merging tables ¶ While pandas uses the merge method to combine data from multiple DataFrames , Ibis uses the join method. They both have similar capabilities. The signature for the join method in Ibis is: join(right, predicates=(), how='inner', *, suffixes=('_x', '_y')) . The merge method on pandas' DataFrame allows many more parameters, but the signature with the corresponding parameters would be: join(right, on=(), how='inner', *, suffixes=('_x', '_y')) . The valid values of the how= parameter will vary depending on the backend, but common values are 'inner', 'outer', 'left', and 'right'. The biggest difference between Ibis' join method and pandas' merge method is that pandas only accepts column names or index levels to join on, whereas Ibis can merge on expressions. Here are some examples of merging using pandas. In [54]: Copied! df_left = pd . DataFrame ([ [ 'a' , 1 , 2 ], [ 'b' , 3 , 4 ], [ 'c' , 4 , 6 ], ], columns = [ 'name' , 'x' , 'y' ]) df_right = pd . DataFrame ([ [ 'a' , 100 , 200 ], [ 'm' , 300 , 400 ], [ 'n' , 400 , 600 ], ], columns = [ 'name' , 'x_100' , 'y_100' ]) df_left = pd.DataFrame([ ['a', 1, 2], ['b', 3, 4], ['c', 4, 6], ], columns=['name', 'x', 'y']) df_right = pd.DataFrame([ ['a', 100, 200], ['m', 300, 400], ['n', 400, 600], ], columns=['name', 'x_100', 'y_100']) In [55]: Copied! df_left . merge ( df_right , on = 'name' ) df_left.merge(df_right, on='name') Out[55]: .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type { vertical-align: middle; } .dataframe tbody tr th { vertical-align: top; } .dataframe thead th { text-align: right; } name x y x_100 y_100 0 a 1 2 100 200 In [56]: Copied! df_left . merge ( df_right , on = 'name' , how = 'outer' ) df_left.merge(df_right, on='name', how='outer') Out[56]: .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type { vertical-align: middle; } .dataframe tbody tr th { vertical-align: top; } .dataframe thead th { text-align: right; } name x y x_100 y_100 0 a 1.0 2.0 100.0 200.0 1 b 3.0 4.0 NaN NaN 2 c 4.0 6.0 NaN NaN 3 m NaN NaN 300.0 400.0 4 n NaN NaN 400.0 600.0 We can now convert DataFrames to Ibis tables to do join s. In [57]: Copied! pd_ibis = ibis . pandas . connect ({ 't_left' : df_left , 't_right' : df_right }) t_left = pd_ibis . table ( 't_left' ) t_right = pd_ibis . table ( 't_right' ) pd_ibis = ibis.pandas.connect({'t_left': df_left, 't_right': df_right}) t_left = pd_ibis.table('t_left') t_right = pd_ibis.table('t_right') In [58]: Copied! t_left . join ( t_right , t_left . name == t_right . name ) t_left.join(t_right, t_left.name == t_right.name) Out[58]: ┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓ ┃ name ┃ x ┃ y ┃ x_100 ┃ y_100 ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ int64 │ int64 │ int64 │ ├────────┼───────┼───────┼───────┼───────┤ │ a │ 1 │ 2 │ 100 │ 200 │ └────────┴───────┴───────┴───────┴───────┘ You may notice that in Ibis joins, even if the predicate is an equality expression and both tables have the same column name, you will still get multiple output columns with suffixes added. This may change in a future version to match the pandas behavior. Below is an outer join where missing values are filled with NaN . In [59]: Copied! t_left . join ( t_right , t_left . name == t_right . name , how = 'outer' ) t_left.join(t_right, t_left.name == t_right.name, how='outer') Out[59]: ┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓ ┃ name_x ┃ x ┃ y ┃ name_y ┃ x_100 ┃ y_100 ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ int64 │ string │ int64 │ int64 │ ├────────┼───────┼───────┼────────┼───────┼───────┤ │ a │ 1 │ 2 │ a │ 100 │ 200 │ │ b │ 3 │ 4 │ b │ ∅ │ ∅ │ │ c │ 4 │ 6 │ c │ ∅ │ ∅ │ │ m │ ∅ │ ∅ │ m │ 300 │ 400 │ │ n │ ∅ │ ∅ │ n │ 400 │ 600 │ └────────┴───────┴───────┴────────┴───────┴───────┘ Concatenating tables ¶ Concatenating DataFrame s in pandas is done with the concat top-level function. It takes multiple DataFrames and concatenates the rows of one DataFrame to the next. If the columns are mis-matched, it extends the list of columns to include the full set of columns and inserts NaN s and None s into the missing values. Concatenating tables in Ibis can only be done on tables with matching schemas. The concatenation is done using the top-level union function or the union method on a table. We'll demonstrate a pandas concat first. In [60]: Copied! df_1 = pd . DataFrame ([ [ 'a' , 1 , 2 ], [ 'b' , 3 , 4 ], [ 'c' , 4 , 6 ], ], columns = [ 'name' , 'x' , 'y' ]) df_2 = pd . DataFrame ([ [ 'a' , 100 , 200 ], [ 'm' , 300 , 400 ], [ 'n' , 400 , 600 ], ], columns = [ 'name' , 'x' , 'y' ]) df_1 = pd.DataFrame([ ['a', 1, 2], ['b', 3, 4], ['c', 4, 6], ], columns=['name', 'x', 'y']) df_2 = pd.DataFrame([ ['a', 100, 200], ['m', 300, 400], ['n', 400, 600], ], columns=['name', 'x', 'y']) In [61]: Copied! pd . concat ([ df_1 , df_2 ]) pd.concat([df_1, df_2]) Out[61]: .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type { vertical-align: middle; } .dataframe tbody tr th { vertical-align: top; } .dataframe thead th { text-align: right; } name x y 0 a 1 2 1 b 3 4 2 c 4 6 0 a 100 200 1 m 300 400 2 n 400 600 Now we can convert the DataFrame s to Ibis tables and combine the tables using a union. In [62]: Copied! pd_ibis = ibis . pandas . connect ({ 't_1' : df_1 , 't_2' : df_2 }) t_1 = pd_ibis . table ( 't_1' ) t_2 = pd_ibis . table ( 't_2' ) pd_ibis = ibis.pandas.connect({'t_1': df_1, 't_2': df_2}) t_1 = pd_ibis.table('t_1') t_2 = pd_ibis.table('t_2') In [63]: Copied! unioned = ibis . union ( t_1 , t_2 ) unioned unioned = ibis.union(t_1, t_2) unioned Out[63]: ┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓ ┃ name ┃ x ┃ y ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ int64 │ ├────────┼───────┼───────┤ │ a │ 1 │ 2 │ │ b │ 3 │ 4 │ │ c │ 4 │ 6 │ │ a │ 100 │ 200 │ │ m │ 300 │ 400 │ │ n │ 400 │ 600 │ └────────┴───────┴───────┘
docs.title: Ibis for pandas Users

docs.text: Much of the syntax and many of the operations in Ibis are inspired by the pandas DataFrame, however, the primary domain of Ibis is SQL so there are some differences in how they operate. One primary difference between Ibis tables and pandas DataFrame s are that many of the pandas DataFrame operations do in-place operations (they are "mutable"), whereas Ibis table operations always return a new table expression ("immutable"). Another difference is that Ibis expressions are lazy, meaning that as you build up an expression, no computation is actually performed until you call an action method such as execute . Only then does Ibis compile the expression into SQL and send it to the backend. (Note that we'll be using Ibis' interactive mode to automatically execute queries at the end of each cell in this notebook. If you are using similar code in a program, you will have to add .execute() to each operation that you want to evaluate.) In [1]: Copied! import ibis import pandas as pd ibis . options . interactive = True import ibis import pandas as pd ibis.options.interactive = True We'll be using the pandas backend in Ibis in the examples below. First we'll create a simple DataFrame . In [2]: Copied! df = pd . DataFrame ( [ [ 'a' , 1 , 2 ], [ 'b' , 3 , 4 ] ], columns = [ 'one' , 'two' , 'three' ], index = [ 5 , 6 ], ) df df = pd.DataFrame( [ ['a', 1, 2], ['b', 3, 4] ], columns=['one', 'two', 'three'], index=[5,6], ) df Out[2]: .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type { vertical-align: middle; } .dataframe tbody tr th { vertical-align: top; } .dataframe thead th { text-align: right; } one two three 5 a 1 2 6 b 3 4 Now we can create an Ibis table from the above DataFrame . Note that the index from the Pandas DataFrame is dropped. Ibis has no notion of an index: If you want to use the index, you will need to turn it into a column. In [3]: Copied! t = ibis . pandas . connect ({ 't' : df }) . table ( 't' ) t t = ibis.pandas.connect({'t': df}).table('t') t Out[3]: ┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓ ┃ one ┃ two ┃ three ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ int64 │ ├────────┼───────┼───────┤ │ a │ 1 │ 2 │ │ b │ 3 │ 4 │ └────────┴───────┴───────┘
docs.title: Ibis for pandas Users

docs.text: The data types of columns in pandas are accessed using the dtypes attribute. This returns a Series object. In [4]: Copied! df . dtypes df.dtypes Out[4]: one object two int64 three int64 dtype: object In Ibis, you use the schema method which returns an ibis.Schema object. In [5]: Copied! t . schema () t.schema() Out[5]: ibis.Schema { one string two int64 three int64 } It is possible to convert the schema information to pandas data types using the to_pandas method, if needed. In [6]: Copied! t . schema () . to_pandas () t.schema().to_pandas() Out[6]: [('one', dtype('O')), ('two', dtype('int64')), ('three', dtype('int64'))]
docs.title: Data types

docs.text: In pandas, the layout of the table is contained in the shape attribute which contains the number of rows and number of columns in a tuple. The number of columns in an Ibis table can be gotten from the length of the schema. In [7]: Copied! len ( t . schema ()) len(t.schema()) Out[7]: 3 To get the number of rows of a table, you use the count method. In [8]: Copied! t . count () t.count() Out[8]: 2 To mimic pandas' behavior, you would use the following code. Note that you need to use the execute method after count to evaluate the expression returned by count . In [9]: Copied! ( t . count () . execute (), len ( t . schema ())) (t.count().execute(), len(t.schema())) Out[9]: (2, 3) In [10]: Copied! df . shape df.shape Out[10]: (2, 3)
docs.title: Table layout

docs.text: Selecting columns is very similar to in pandas. In fact, you can use the same syntax. In [11]: Copied! t [[ 'one' , 'two' ]] t[['one', 'two']] Out[11]: ┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓ ┃ one ┃ two ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ ├────────┼───────┤ │ a │ 1 │ │ b │ 3 │ └────────┴───────┘ However, since row-level indexing is not supported in Ibis, the inner list is not necessary. In [12]: Copied! t [ 'one' , 'two' ] t['one', 'two'] Out[12]: ┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓ ┃ one ┃ two ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ ├────────┼───────┤ │ a │ 1 │ │ b │ 3 │ └────────┴───────┘
docs.title: Subsetting columns

docs.text: Selecting columns is done using the same syntax as in pandas DataFrames . You can use either the indexing syntax or attribute syntax. In [13]: Copied! t [ 'one' ] t['one'] Out[13]: ┏━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ one ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ ├────────┤ │ a │ │ b │ └────────┘ or: In [14]: Copied! t . one t.one Out[14]: ┏━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ one ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ ├────────┤ │ a │ │ b │ └────────┘
docs.title: Selecting columns

docs.text: Modifying the columns of an Ibis table is a bit different than doing the same operations in a pandas DataFrame . This is primarily due to the fact that in-place operations are not supported on Ibis tables. Each time you do a column modification to a table, a new table expression is returned.
docs.title: Adding, removing, and modifying columns

docs.text: Adding columns is done through the mutate method. In [15]: Copied! mutated = t . mutate ( new_col = t . three * 2 ) mutated mutated = t.mutate(new_col=t.three * 2) mutated Out[15]: ┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ one ┃ two ┃ three ┃ new_col ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ int64 │ int64 │ ├────────┼───────┼───────┼─────────┤ │ a │ 1 │ 2 │ 4 │ │ b │ 3 │ 4 │ 8 │ └────────┴───────┴───────┴─────────┘ Notice that the original table object remains unchanged. Only the mutated object that was returned contains the new column. In [16]: Copied! t t Out[16]: ┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓ ┃ one ┃ two ┃ three ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ int64 │ ├────────┼───────┼───────┤ │ a │ 1 │ 2 │ │ b │ 3 │ 4 │ └────────┴───────┴───────┘ It is also possible to create a column in isolation. This is similar to a Series in pandas. Note that the name of the column by default is a representation of the expression: In [17]: Copied! unnamed = ( t . three * 2 ) unnamed unnamed = (t.three * 2) unnamed Out[17]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ Multiply(three, 2) ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩ │ int64 │ ├────────────────────┤ │ 4 │ │ 8 │ └────────────────────┘ To get a version with a specific name, you can use the name method: In [18]: Copied! new_col = unnamed . name ( "new_col" ) new_col new_col = unnamed.name("new_col") new_col Out[18]: ┏━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ new_col ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━┩ │ int64 │ ├─────────┤ │ 4 │ │ 8 │ └─────────┘ You can then add this column to the table using a projection. In [19]: Copied! proj = t [ 'one' , 'two' , new_col ] proj proj = t['one', 'two', new_col] proj Out[19]: ┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ one ┃ two ┃ new_col ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ int64 │ ├────────┼───────┼─────────┤ │ a │ 1 │ 4 │ │ b │ 3 │ 8 │ └────────┴───────┴─────────┘
docs.title: Adding columns

docs.text: Removing a column is done using the drop method. In [20]: Copied! t . columns t.columns Out[20]: ['one', 'two', 'three'] In [21]: Copied! subset = t . drop ( 'one' , 'two' ) subset . columns subset = t.drop('one', 'two') subset.columns Out[21]: ['three'] It is also possible to drop columns by selecting the columns you want to remain. In [22]: Copied! subset = t [ 'two' , 'three' ] subset . columns subset = t['two', 'three'] subset.columns Out[22]: ['two', 'three']
docs.title: Removing columns

docs.text: Replacing existing columns is done using the mutate method just like adding columns. You simply add a column of the same name to replace it. In [23]: Copied! t t Out[23]: ┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓ ┃ one ┃ two ┃ three ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ int64 │ ├────────┼───────┼───────┤ │ a │ 1 │ 2 │ │ b │ 3 │ 4 │ └────────┴───────┴───────┘ In [24]: Copied! mutated = t . mutate ( two = t . two * 2 ) mutated mutated = t.mutate(two=t.two * 2) mutated Out[24]: ┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓ ┃ one ┃ two ┃ three ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ int64 │ ├────────┼───────┼───────┤ │ a │ 2 │ 2 │ │ b │ 6 │ 4 │ └────────┴───────┴───────┘
docs.title: Modifying columns

docs.text: In addition to replacing columns, you can simply rename them as well. This is done with the relabel method which takes a dictionary containing the name mappings. In [25]: Copied! relabeled = t . relabel ( dict ( one = 'a' , two = 'b' , )) relabeled relabeled = t.relabel(dict( one='a', two='b', )) relabeled Out[25]: ┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓ ┃ a ┃ b ┃ three ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ int64 │ ├────────┼───────┼───────┤ │ a │ 1 │ 2 │ │ b │ 3 │ 4 │ └────────┴───────┴───────┘
docs.title: Renaming columns

docs.text: There are several methods that can be used to select rows of data in various ways. These are described in the sections below. We'll use the ubiquitous iris dataset for these examples. In [26]: Copied! df = pd . read_csv ( 'https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mwaskom/seaborn-data/master/iris.csv' ) df . head () df = pd.read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mwaskom/seaborn-data/master/iris.csv') df.head() Out[26]: .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type { vertical-align: middle; } .dataframe tbody tr th { vertical-align: top; } .dataframe thead th { text-align: right; } sepal_length sepal_width petal_length petal_width species 0 5.1 3.5 1.4 0.2 setosa 1 4.9 3.0 1.4 0.2 setosa 2 4.7 3.2 1.3 0.2 setosa 3 4.6 3.1 1.5 0.2 setosa 4 5.0 3.6 1.4 0.2 setosa Create an Ibis table from the DataFrame above. In [27]: Copied! t = ibis . pandas . connect ({ 't' : df }) . table ( 't' ) t t = ibis.pandas.connect({'t': df}).table('t') t Out[27]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ sepal_length ┃ sepal_width ┃ petal_length ┃ petal_width ┃ species ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ string │ ├──────────────┼─────────────┼──────────────┼─────────────┼─────────┤ │ 5.1 │ 3.5 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.9 │ 3.0 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.7 │ 3.2 │ 1.3 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.6 │ 3.1 │ 1.5 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 5.0 │ 3.6 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 5.4 │ 3.9 │ 1.7 │ 0.4 │ setosa │ │ 4.6 │ 3.4 │ 1.4 │ 0.3 │ setosa │ │ 5.0 │ 3.4 │ 1.5 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.4 │ 2.9 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.9 │ 3.1 │ 1.5 │ 0.1 │ setosa │ │ … │ … │ … │ … │ … │ └──────────────┴─────────────┴──────────────┴─────────────┴─────────┘
docs.title: Selecting rows

docs.text: The head method works the same ways as in pandas. Note that some Ibis backends may not have an inherent ordering of their rows and using head may not return deterministic results. In those cases, you can use sorting before calling head to ensure a stable result. In [28]: Copied! t . head ( 5 ) t.head(5) Out[28]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ sepal_length ┃ sepal_width ┃ petal_length ┃ petal_width ┃ species ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ string │ ├──────────────┼─────────────┼──────────────┼─────────────┼─────────┤ │ 5.1 │ 3.5 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.9 │ 3.0 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.7 │ 3.2 │ 1.3 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.6 │ 3.1 │ 1.5 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 5.0 │ 3.6 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ └──────────────┴─────────────┴──────────────┴─────────────┴─────────┘ However, the tail method is not implemented since it is not supported in all databases. It is possible to emulate the tail method if you use sorting in your table to do a reverse sort then use the head method to retrieve the "top" rows. Another way to limit the number of retrieved rows is using the limit method. The following will return the same result as head(5) . This is often used in conjunction with other filtering techniques that we will cover later. In [29]: Copied! t . limit ( 5 ) t.limit(5) Out[29]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ sepal_length ┃ sepal_width ┃ petal_length ┃ petal_width ┃ species ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ string │ ├──────────────┼─────────────┼──────────────┼─────────────┼─────────┤ │ 5.1 │ 3.5 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.9 │ 3.0 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.7 │ 3.2 │ 1.3 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.6 │ 3.1 │ 1.5 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 5.0 │ 3.6 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ └──────────────┴─────────────┴──────────────┴─────────────┴─────────┘ The starting position of the returned rows can be specified using the offset parameter. In [30]: Copied! t . limit ( 5 , offset = 4 ) t.limit(5, offset=4) Out[30]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ sepal_length ┃ sepal_width ┃ petal_length ┃ petal_width ┃ species ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ string │ ├──────────────┼─────────────┼──────────────┼─────────────┼─────────┤ │ 5.0 │ 3.6 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 5.4 │ 3.9 │ 1.7 │ 0.4 │ setosa │ │ 4.6 │ 3.4 │ 1.4 │ 0.3 │ setosa │ │ 5.0 │ 3.4 │ 1.5 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.4 │ 2.9 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ └──────────────┴─────────────┴──────────────┴─────────────┴─────────┘
docs.title: Head, tail and limit

docs.text: In addition to simply limiting the number of rows that are returned, it is possible to filter the rows using expressions. Expressions are constructed very similarly to the way they are in pandas. Ibis expressions are constructed from operations on colunms in a table which return a boolean result. This result is then used to filter the table. In [31]: Copied! expr = t . sepal_width > 3.8 expr expr = t.sepal_width > 3.8 expr Out[31]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ Greater(sepal_width, 3.8) ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩ │ boolean │ ├───────────────────────────┤ │ False │ │ False │ │ False │ │ False │ │ False │ │ True │ │ False │ │ False │ │ False │ │ False │ │ … │ └───────────────────────────┘ We can evaluate the value counts to see how many rows we will expect to get back after filtering. In [32]: Copied! expr . value_counts () expr.value_counts() Out[32]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ Greater(sepal_width, 3.8) ┃ Greater(sepal_width, 3.8)_count ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩ │ boolean │ int64 │ ├───────────────────────────┼─────────────────────────────────┤ │ False │ 144 │ │ True │ 6 │ └───────────────────────────┴─────────────────────────────────┘ Now we apply the filter to the table. Since there are 6 True values in the expression, we should get 6 rows back. In [33]: Copied! filtered = t [ expr ] filtered filtered = t[expr] filtered Out[33]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ sepal_length ┃ sepal_width ┃ petal_length ┃ petal_width ┃ species ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ string │ ├──────────────┼─────────────┼──────────────┼─────────────┼─────────┤ │ 5.4 │ 3.9 │ 1.7 │ 0.4 │ setosa │ │ 5.8 │ 4.0 │ 1.2 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 5.7 │ 4.4 │ 1.5 │ 0.4 │ setosa │ │ 5.4 │ 3.9 │ 1.3 │ 0.4 │ setosa │ │ 5.2 │ 4.1 │ 1.5 │ 0.1 │ setosa │ │ 5.5 │ 4.2 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ └──────────────┴─────────────┴──────────────┴─────────────┴─────────┘ Of course, the filtering expression can be applied inline as well. In [34]: Copied! filtered = t [ t . sepal_width > 3.8 ] filtered filtered = t[t.sepal_width > 3.8] filtered Out[34]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ sepal_length ┃ sepal_width ┃ petal_length ┃ petal_width ┃ species ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ string │ ├──────────────┼─────────────┼──────────────┼─────────────┼─────────┤ │ 5.4 │ 3.9 │ 1.7 │ 0.4 │ setosa │ │ 5.8 │ 4.0 │ 1.2 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 5.7 │ 4.4 │ 1.5 │ 0.4 │ setosa │ │ 5.4 │ 3.9 │ 1.3 │ 0.4 │ setosa │ │ 5.2 │ 4.1 │ 1.5 │ 0.1 │ setosa │ │ 5.5 │ 4.2 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ └──────────────┴─────────────┴──────────────┴─────────────┴─────────┘ Multiple filtering expressions can be combined into a single expression or chained onto existing table expressions. In [35]: Copied! filtered = t [( t . sepal_width > 3.8 ) & ( t . sepal_length > 5.5 )] filtered filtered = t[(t.sepal_width > 3.8) & (t.sepal_length > 5.5)] filtered Out[35]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ sepal_length ┃ sepal_width ┃ petal_length ┃ petal_width ┃ species ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ string │ ├──────────────┼─────────────┼──────────────┼─────────────┼─────────┤ │ 5.8 │ 4.0 │ 1.2 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 5.7 │ 4.4 │ 1.5 │ 0.4 │ setosa │ └──────────────┴─────────────┴──────────────┴─────────────┴─────────┘ The code above will return the same rows as the code below. In [36]: Copied! filtered = t [ t . sepal_width > 3.8 ][ t . sepal_length > 5.5 ] filtered filtered = t[t.sepal_width > 3.8][t.sepal_length > 5.5] filtered Out[36]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ sepal_length ┃ sepal_width ┃ petal_length ┃ petal_width ┃ species ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ string │ ├──────────────┼─────────────┼──────────────┼─────────────┼─────────┤ │ 5.8 │ 4.0 │ 1.2 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 5.7 │ 4.4 │ 1.5 │ 0.4 │ setosa │ └──────────────┴─────────────┴──────────────┴─────────────┴─────────┘ Aggregation has not been discussed yet, but aggregate values can be used in expressions to return things such as all of the rows in a data set where the value in a column is greater than the mean. In [37]: Copied! filtered = t [ t . sepal_width > t . sepal_width . mean ()] filtered filtered = t[t.sepal_width > t.sepal_width.mean()] filtered Out[37]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ sepal_length ┃ sepal_width ┃ petal_length ┃ petal_width ┃ species ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ string │ ├──────────────┼─────────────┼──────────────┼─────────────┼─────────┤ │ 5.1 │ 3.5 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.7 │ 3.2 │ 1.3 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.6 │ 3.1 │ 1.5 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 5.0 │ 3.6 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 5.4 │ 3.9 │ 1.7 │ 0.4 │ setosa │ │ 4.6 │ 3.4 │ 1.4 │ 0.3 │ setosa │ │ 5.0 │ 3.4 │ 1.5 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.9 │ 3.1 │ 1.5 │ 0.1 │ setosa │ │ 5.4 │ 3.7 │ 1.5 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.8 │ 3.4 │ 1.6 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ … │ … │ … │ … │ … │ └──────────────┴─────────────┴──────────────┴─────────────┴─────────┘
docs.title: Filtering rows

docs.text: Sometimes you want to modify the values in a column based on some condition. In pandas, you would do something like df.loc[condition] = new_value . In Ibis though, remember that all expressions are immutable, so you need to create a new table expression with the modified values. You do this using the ifelse method on boolean columns: In [38]: Copied! wide_sepals = t . sepal_width > 3.3 species_modified = wide_sepals . ifelse ( 'wide' , t . species ) t . mutate ( species_modified = species_modified ) wide_sepals = t.sepal_width > 3.3 species_modified = wide_sepals.ifelse('wide', t.species) t.mutate(species_modified=species_modified) Out[38]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ sepal_length ┃ sepal_width ┃ petal_length ┃ petal_width ┃ species ┃ species_modified ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ string │ string │ ├──────────────┼─────────────┼──────────────┼─────────────┼─────────┼──────────────────┤ │ 5.1 │ 3.5 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ wide │ │ 4.9 │ 3.0 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ setosa │ │ 4.7 │ 3.2 │ 1.3 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ setosa │ │ 4.6 │ 3.1 │ 1.5 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ setosa │ │ 5.0 │ 3.6 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ wide │ │ 5.4 │ 3.9 │ 1.7 │ 0.4 │ setosa │ wide │ │ 4.6 │ 3.4 │ 1.4 │ 0.3 │ setosa │ wide │ │ 5.0 │ 3.4 │ 1.5 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ wide │ │ 4.4 │ 2.9 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ setosa │ │ 4.9 │ 3.1 │ 1.5 │ 0.1 │ setosa │ setosa │ │ … │ … │ … │ … │ … │ … │ └──────────────┴─────────────┴──────────────┴─────────────┴─────────┴──────────────────┘
docs.title: Modifying rows

docs.text: Sorting rows in Ibis uses a somewhat different API than in pandas. In pandas, you would use the sort_values method to order rows by values in specified columns. Ibis uses a method called order_by . To specify ascending or descending orders, pandas uses an ascending= argument to sort_values that indicates the order for each sorting column. Ibis allows you to tag the column name in the order_by list as ascending or descending by wrapping it with ibis.asc or ibis.desc . Here is an example of sorting a DataFrame using two sort keys. One key is sorting in ascending order and the other is in descending order. In [39]: Copied! df . sort_values ([ 'sepal_length' , 'sepal_width' ], ascending = [ True , False ]) . head ( 5 ) df.sort_values(['sepal_length', 'sepal_width'], ascending=[True, False]).head(5) Out[39]: .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type { vertical-align: middle; } .dataframe tbody tr th { vertical-align: top; } .dataframe thead th { text-align: right; } sepal_length sepal_width petal_length petal_width species 13 4.3 3.0 1.1 0.1 setosa 42 4.4 3.2 1.3 0.2 setosa 38 4.4 3.0 1.3 0.2 setosa 8 4.4 2.9 1.4 0.2 setosa 41 4.5 2.3 1.3 0.3 setosa The same operation in Ibis would look like the following. Note that the index values of the resulting DataFrame start from zero and count up, whereas in the example above, they retain their original index value. This is simply due to the fact that rows in tables don't necessarily have a stable index in database backends, so the index is just generated on the result. In [40]: Copied! sorted = t . order_by ([ 'sepal_length' , ibis . desc ( 'sepal_width' )]) . head ( 5 ) sorted sorted = t.order_by(['sepal_length', ibis.desc('sepal_width')]).head(5) sorted Out[40]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ sepal_length ┃ sepal_width ┃ petal_length ┃ petal_width ┃ species ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ float64 │ string │ ├──────────────┼─────────────┼──────────────┼─────────────┼─────────┤ │ 4.3 │ 3.0 │ 1.1 │ 0.1 │ setosa │ │ 4.4 │ 3.2 │ 1.3 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.4 │ 3.0 │ 1.3 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.4 │ 2.9 │ 1.4 │ 0.2 │ setosa │ │ 4.5 │ 2.3 │ 1.3 │ 0.3 │ setosa │ └──────────────┴─────────────┴──────────────┴─────────────┴─────────┘
docs.title: Sorting rows

docs.text: Aggregation in pandas is typically done by computing columns based on an aggregate function. In [41]: Copied! stats = [ df . sepal_width . sum (), df . sepal_length . mean ()] pd . DataFrame ([ stats ], columns = [ 'total_sepal_width' , 'avg.sepal_length' ]) stats = [df.sepal_width.sum(), df.sepal_length.mean()] pd.DataFrame([stats], columns=['total_sepal_width', 'avg.sepal_length']) Out[41]: .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type { vertical-align: middle; } .dataframe tbody tr th { vertical-align: top; } .dataframe thead th { text-align: right; } total_sepal_width avg.sepal_length 0 458.6 5.843333 In Ibis, you construct aggregate expressions then apply them to the table using the aggregate method. In [42]: Copied! stats = [ t . sepal_width . sum () . name ( 'total_sepal_width' ), t . sepal_length . mean () . name ( 'avg_sepal_length' )] agged = t . aggregate ( stats ) agged stats = [t.sepal_width.sum().name('total_sepal_width'), t.sepal_length.mean().name('avg_sepal_length')] agged = t.aggregate(stats) agged Out[42]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ total_sepal_width ┃ avg_sepal_length ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ ├───────────────────┼──────────────────┤ │ 458.6 │ 5.843333 │ └───────────────────┴──────────────────┘ You can also combine both operations into one and pass the aggregate expressions using keyword parameters. In [43]: Copied! agged = t . aggregate ( total_sepal_width = t . sepal_width . sum (), avg_sepal_length = t . sepal_length . mean (), ) agged agged = t.aggregate( total_sepal_width=t.sepal_width.sum(), avg_sepal_length=t.sepal_length.mean(), ) agged Out[43]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ total_sepal_width ┃ avg_sepal_length ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩ │ float64 │ float64 │ ├───────────────────┼──────────────────┤ │ 458.6 │ 5.843333 │ └───────────────────┴──────────────────┘
docs.title: Aggregation

docs.text: Aggregations can also be done across groupings using the by= parameter. In [44]: Copied! agged = t . aggregate ( by = 'species' , total_sepal_width = t . sepal_width . sum (), avg_sepal_length = t . sepal_length . mean (), ) agged agged = t.aggregate( by='species', total_sepal_width=t.sepal_width.sum(), avg_sepal_length=t.sepal_length.mean(), ) agged Out[44]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ species ┃ total_sepal_width ┃ avg_sepal_length ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ float64 │ float64 │ ├────────────┼───────────────────┼──────────────────┤ │ setosa │ 171.4 │ 5.006 │ │ versicolor │ 138.5 │ 5.936 │ │ virginica │ 148.7 │ 6.588 │ └────────────┴───────────────────┴──────────────────┘ Alternatively, by groups can be computed using a grouped table. In [45]: Copied! agged = t . group_by ( 'species' ) . aggregate ( total_sepal_width = t . sepal_width . sum (), avg_sepal_length = t . sepal_length . mean (), ) agged agged = t.group_by('species').aggregate( total_sepal_width=t.sepal_width.sum(), avg_sepal_length=t.sepal_length.mean(), ) agged Out[45]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ species ┃ total_sepal_width ┃ avg_sepal_length ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ float64 │ float64 │ ├────────────┼───────────────────┼──────────────────┤ │ setosa │ 171.4 │ 5.006 │ │ versicolor │ 138.5 │ 5.936 │ │ virginica │ 148.7 │ 6.588 │ └────────────┴───────────────────┴──────────────────┘
docs.title: Group by

docs.text: Both pandas and Ibis allow you to drop rows from a table based on whether a set of columns contains a NULL value. This method is called dropna in both packages. The common set of parameters in the two are subset= and how= . The subset= parameter indicates which columns to inspect for NULL values. The how= parameter specifies whether 'any' or 'all' of the specified columns must be NULL in order for the row to be dropped. In [46]: Copied! no_null_t = t . dropna ([ 'sepal_width' , 'sepal_length' ], how = 'any' ) no_null_t = t.dropna(['sepal_width', 'sepal_length'], how='any')
docs.title: Dropping rows with NULLs

docs.text: Both pandas and Ibis allow you to fill NULL values in a table. In Ibis, the replacement value can only be a scalar value of a dictionary of values. If it is a dictionary, the keys of the dictionary specify the column name for the value to apply to. In [47]: Copied! no_null_t = t . fillna ( dict ( sepal_width = 0 , sepal_length = 0 )) no_null_t = t.fillna(dict(sepal_width=0, sepal_length=0))
docs.title: Filling NULL values

docs.text: See the full API documentation for all of the available value methods and tools for creating value expressions. We mention a few common ones here as they relate to common SQL queries.
docs.title: Common column expressions

docs.text: Type casting in pandas is done using the astype method on columns. In [48]: Copied! df . sepal_width . astype ( str ) df.sepal_width.astype(str) Out[48]: 0 3.5 1 3.0 2 3.2 3 3.1 4 3.6 ... 145 3.0 146 2.5 147 3.0 148 3.4 149 3.0 Name: sepal_width, Length: 150, dtype: object In Ibis, you cast the column type using the cast method. In [49]: Copied! t . sepal_width . cast ( 'int' ) t.sepal_width.cast('int') Out[49]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ Cast(sepal_width, int64) ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩ │ int64 │ ├──────────────────────────┤ │ 3 │ │ 3 │ │ 3 │ │ 3 │ │ 3 │ │ 3 │ │ 3 │ │ 3 │ │ 2 │ │ 3 │ │ … │ └──────────────────────────┘ Casted columns can be assigned back to the table using the mutate method described earlier. In [50]: Copied! casted = t . mutate ( sepal_width = t . sepal_width . cast ( 'int' ), sepal_length = t . sepal_length . cast ( 'int' ), ) casted . schema () casted = t.mutate( sepal_width=t.sepal_width.cast('int'), sepal_length=t.sepal_length.cast('int'), ) casted.schema() Out[50]: ibis.Schema { sepal_length int64 sepal_width int64 petal_length float64 petal_width float64 species string }
docs.title: Type casts

docs.text: Both pandas and Ibis have fillna methods which allow you to specify a replacement value for NULL values. In [51]: Copied! sepal_length_no_nulls = t . sepal_length . fillna ( 0 ) sepal_length_no_nulls = t.sepal_length.fillna(0)
docs.title: Replacing NULLs

docs.text: pandas set membership uses the in and not in operators such as 'a' in df.species . Ibis uses isin and notin methods. In addition to testing membership in a set, these methods allow you to specify an else case to assign a value when the value isn't in the set. In [52]: Copied! t . species . value_counts () t.species.value_counts() Out[52]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ species ┃ species_count ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ ├────────────┼───────────────┤ │ setosa │ 50 │ │ versicolor │ 50 │ │ virginica │ 50 │ └────────────┴───────────────┘ In [53]: Copied! refined = t . species . isin ([ 'versicolor' , 'virginica' ]) refined . value_counts () refined = t.species.isin(['versicolor', 'virginica']) refined.value_counts() Out[53]: ┏━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┓ ┃ Contains(species) ┃ Contains(species)_count ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━┩ │ boolean │ int64 │ ├───────────────────┼─────────────────────────┤ │ False │ 50 │ │ True │ 100 │ └───────────────────┴─────────────────────────┘
docs.title: Set membership

docs.text: While pandas uses the merge method to combine data from multiple DataFrames , Ibis uses the join method. They both have similar capabilities. The signature for the join method in Ibis is: join(right, predicates=(), how='inner', *, suffixes=('_x', '_y')) . The merge method on pandas' DataFrame allows many more parameters, but the signature with the corresponding parameters would be: join(right, on=(), how='inner', *, suffixes=('_x', '_y')) . The valid values of the how= parameter will vary depending on the backend, but common values are 'inner', 'outer', 'left', and 'right'. The biggest difference between Ibis' join method and pandas' merge method is that pandas only accepts column names or index levels to join on, whereas Ibis can merge on expressions. Here are some examples of merging using pandas. In [54]: Copied! df_left = pd . DataFrame ([ [ 'a' , 1 , 2 ], [ 'b' , 3 , 4 ], [ 'c' , 4 , 6 ], ], columns = [ 'name' , 'x' , 'y' ]) df_right = pd . DataFrame ([ [ 'a' , 100 , 200 ], [ 'm' , 300 , 400 ], [ 'n' , 400 , 600 ], ], columns = [ 'name' , 'x_100' , 'y_100' ]) df_left = pd.DataFrame([ ['a', 1, 2], ['b', 3, 4], ['c', 4, 6], ], columns=['name', 'x', 'y']) df_right = pd.DataFrame([ ['a', 100, 200], ['m', 300, 400], ['n', 400, 600], ], columns=['name', 'x_100', 'y_100']) In [55]: Copied! df_left . merge ( df_right , on = 'name' ) df_left.merge(df_right, on='name') Out[55]: .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type { vertical-align: middle; } .dataframe tbody tr th { vertical-align: top; } .dataframe thead th { text-align: right; } name x y x_100 y_100 0 a 1 2 100 200 In [56]: Copied! df_left . merge ( df_right , on = 'name' , how = 'outer' ) df_left.merge(df_right, on='name', how='outer') Out[56]: .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type { vertical-align: middle; } .dataframe tbody tr th { vertical-align: top; } .dataframe thead th { text-align: right; } name x y x_100 y_100 0 a 1.0 2.0 100.0 200.0 1 b 3.0 4.0 NaN NaN 2 c 4.0 6.0 NaN NaN 3 m NaN NaN 300.0 400.0 4 n NaN NaN 400.0 600.0 We can now convert DataFrames to Ibis tables to do join s. In [57]: Copied! pd_ibis = ibis . pandas . connect ({ 't_left' : df_left , 't_right' : df_right }) t_left = pd_ibis . table ( 't_left' ) t_right = pd_ibis . table ( 't_right' ) pd_ibis = ibis.pandas.connect({'t_left': df_left, 't_right': df_right}) t_left = pd_ibis.table('t_left') t_right = pd_ibis.table('t_right') In [58]: Copied! t_left . join ( t_right , t_left . name == t_right . name ) t_left.join(t_right, t_left.name == t_right.name) Out[58]: ┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓ ┃ name ┃ x ┃ y ┃ x_100 ┃ y_100 ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ int64 │ int64 │ int64 │ ├────────┼───────┼───────┼───────┼───────┤ │ a │ 1 │ 2 │ 100 │ 200 │ └────────┴───────┴───────┴───────┴───────┘ You may notice that in Ibis joins, even if the predicate is an equality expression and both tables have the same column name, you will still get multiple output columns with suffixes added. This may change in a future version to match the pandas behavior. Below is an outer join where missing values are filled with NaN . In [59]: Copied! t_left . join ( t_right , t_left . name == t_right . name , how = 'outer' ) t_left.join(t_right, t_left.name == t_right.name, how='outer') Out[59]: ┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓ ┃ name_x ┃ x ┃ y ┃ name_y ┃ x_100 ┃ y_100 ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ int64 │ string │ int64 │ int64 │ ├────────┼───────┼───────┼────────┼───────┼───────┤ │ a │ 1 │ 2 │ a │ 100 │ 200 │ │ b │ 3 │ 4 │ b │ ∅ │ ∅ │ │ c │ 4 │ 6 │ c │ ∅ │ ∅ │ │ m │ ∅ │ ∅ │ m │ 300 │ 400 │ │ n │ ∅ │ ∅ │ n │ 400 │ 600 │ └────────┴───────┴───────┴────────┴───────┴───────┘
docs.title: Merging tables

docs.text: Concatenating DataFrame s in pandas is done with the concat top-level function. It takes multiple DataFrames and concatenates the rows of one DataFrame to the next. If the columns are mis-matched, it extends the list of columns to include the full set of columns and inserts NaN s and None s into the missing values. Concatenating tables in Ibis can only be done on tables with matching schemas. The concatenation is done using the top-level union function or the union method on a table. We'll demonstrate a pandas concat first. In [60]: Copied! df_1 = pd . DataFrame ([ [ 'a' , 1 , 2 ], [ 'b' , 3 , 4 ], [ 'c' , 4 , 6 ], ], columns = [ 'name' , 'x' , 'y' ]) df_2 = pd . DataFrame ([ [ 'a' , 100 , 200 ], [ 'm' , 300 , 400 ], [ 'n' , 400 , 600 ], ], columns = [ 'name' , 'x' , 'y' ]) df_1 = pd.DataFrame([ ['a', 1, 2], ['b', 3, 4], ['c', 4, 6], ], columns=['name', 'x', 'y']) df_2 = pd.DataFrame([ ['a', 100, 200], ['m', 300, 400], ['n', 400, 600], ], columns=['name', 'x', 'y']) In [61]: Copied! pd . concat ([ df_1 , df_2 ]) pd.concat([df_1, df_2]) Out[61]: .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type { vertical-align: middle; } .dataframe tbody tr th { vertical-align: top; } .dataframe thead th { text-align: right; } name x y 0 a 1 2 1 b 3 4 2 c 4 6 0 a 100 200 1 m 300 400 2 n 400 600 Now we can convert the DataFrame s to Ibis tables and combine the tables using a union. In [62]: Copied! pd_ibis = ibis . pandas . connect ({ 't_1' : df_1 , 't_2' : df_2 }) t_1 = pd_ibis . table ( 't_1' ) t_2 = pd_ibis . table ( 't_2' ) pd_ibis = ibis.pandas.connect({'t_1': df_1, 't_2': df_2}) t_1 = pd_ibis.table('t_1') t_2 = pd_ibis.table('t_2') In [63]: Copied! unioned = ibis . union ( t_1 , t_2 ) unioned unioned = ibis.union(t_1, t_2) unioned Out[63]: ┏━━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┳━━━━━━━┓ ┃ name ┃ x ┃ y ┃ ┡━━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━╇━━━━━━━┩ │ string │ int64 │ int64 │ ├────────┼───────┼───────┤ │ a │ 1 │ 2 │ │ b │ 3 │ 4 │ │ c │ 4 │ 6 │ │ a │ 100 │ 200 │ │ m │ 300 │ 400 │ │ n │ 400 │ 600 │ └────────┴───────┴───────┘
docs.title: Concatenating tables

sourceMappingURL=mkdocs-jupyter.css.map*/ init_mathjax = function() { if (window.MathJax) { // MathJax loaded MathJax.Hub.Config({ TeX: { equationNumbers: { autoNumber: "AMS", useLabelIds: true } }, tex2jax: { inlineMath: [ ['$','$'], ["\\(","\\)"] ], displayMath: [ ['$$','$$'], ["\\[","\\]"] ], processEscapes: true, processEnvironments: true }, displayAlign: 'center', CommonHTML: { linebreaks: { automatic: true } } }); MathJax.Hub.Queue(["Typeset", MathJax.Hub]); } } init_mathjax(); Ibis for SQL Programmers ¶ Ibis provides a full-featured replacement for SQL SELECT queries, but expressed with Python code that is: Type-checked and validated as you go. No more debugging cryptic database errors; Ibis catches your mistakes right away. Easier to write. Pythonic function calls with tab completion in IPython. More composable. Break complex queries down into easier-to-digest pieces Easier to reuse. Mix and match Ibis snippets to create expressions tailored for your analysis. We intend for all SELECT queries to be fully portable to Ibis. Coverage of other DDL statements (e.g. CREATE TABLE or INSERT ) may vary from engine to engine. Note : If you find any SQL idioms or use cases in your work that are not represented here, please reach out so we can add more to this guide! In [1]: Copied! import ibis ibis . options . sql . default_limit = None import ibis ibis.options.sql.default_limit = None Projections: select/add/remove columns ¶ All tables in Ibis are immutable. To select a subset of a table's columns, or to add new columns, you must produce a new table by means of a projection . In [2]: Copied! t = ibis . table ( [( 'one' , 'string' ), ( 'two' , 'float' ), ( 'three' , 'int32' )], 'my_data' ) t t = ibis.table( [('one', 'string'), ('two', 'float'), ('three', 'int32')], 'my_data' ) t Out[2]: UnboundTable: my_data one string two float64 three int32 In SQL, you might write something like: SELECT two , one FROM my_data In Ibis, this is In [3]: Copied! proj = t [ 'two' , 'one' ] proj = t['two', 'one'] or In [4]: Copied! proj = t . projection ([ 'two' , 'one' ]) proj = t.projection(['two', 'one']) This generates the expected SQL: In [5]: Copied! ibis . show_sql ( proj ) ibis.show_sql(proj) SELECT t0.two, t0.one FROM my_data AS t0 What about adding new columns? To form a valid projection, all column expressions must be named . Let's look at the SQL: SELECT two , one , three * 2 AS new_col FROM my_data The last expression is written: In [6]: Copied! new_col = ( t . three * 2 ) . name ( 'new_col' ) new_col = (t.three * 2).name('new_col') Now, we have: In [7]: Copied! proj = t [ 'two' , 'one' , new_col ] ibis . show_sql ( proj ) proj = t['two', 'one', new_col] ibis.show_sql(proj) SELECT t0.two, t0.one, t0.three * CAST(2 AS SMALLINT) AS new_col FROM my_data AS t0 mutate : Add or modify columns easily ¶ Since adding new columns or modifying existing columns is so common, there is a convenience method mutate : In [8]: Copied! mutated = t . mutate ( new_col = t . three * 2 ) mutated = t.mutate(new_col=t.three * 2) Notice that using the name was not necessary here because we're using Python keywords to provide the name. Indeed: In [9]: Copied! ibis . show_sql ( mutated ) ibis.show_sql(mutated) SELECT t0.one, t0.two, t0.three, t0.three * CAST(2 AS SMALLINT) AS new_col FROM my_data AS t0 If you modify an existing column with mutate it will list out all the other columns: In [10]: Copied! mutated = t . mutate ( two = t . two * 2 ) ibis . show_sql ( mutated ) mutated = t.mutate(two=t.two * 2) ibis.show_sql(mutated) SELECT t0.one, t0.two * CAST(2 AS SMALLINT) AS two, t0.three FROM my_data AS t0 SELECT * equivalent ¶ Especially in combination with relational joins, it's convenient to be able to select all columns in a table using the SELECT * construct. To do this, use the table expression itself in a projection: In [11]: Copied! proj = t [ t ] ibis . show_sql ( proj ) proj = t[t] ibis.show_sql(proj) SELECT t0.one, t0.two, t0.three FROM my_data AS t0 This is how mutate is implemented. The example above t.mutate(new_col=t.three * 2) can be written as a normal projection: In [12]: Copied! proj = t [ t , new_col ] ibis . show_sql ( proj ) proj = t[t, new_col] ibis.show_sql(proj) SELECT t0.one, t0.two, t0.three, t0.three * CAST(2 AS SMALLINT) AS new_col FROM my_data AS t0 Let's consider a table we might wish to join with t : In [13]: Copied! t2 = ibis . table ([( 'key' , 'string' ), ( 'value' , 'float' )], 'dim_table' ) t2 = ibis.table([('key', 'string'), ('value', 'float')], 'dim_table') Now let's take the SQL: SELECT t0 . * , t0 . two - t1 . value AS diff FROM my_data t0 INNER JOIN dim_table t1 ON t0 . one = t1 . key To write this with Ibis, it is: In [14]: Copied! diff = ( t . two - t2 . value ) . name ( 'diff' ) joined = t . join ( t2 , t . one == t2 . key )[ t , diff ] diff = (t.two - t2.value).name('diff') joined = t.join(t2, t.one == t2.key)[t, diff] And verify the generated SQL: In [15]: Copied! ibis . show_sql ( joined ) ibis.show_sql(joined) SELECT t0.one, t0.two, t0.three, t0.two - t1.value AS diff FROM my_data AS t0 JOIN dim_table AS t1 ON t0.one = t1.key Using functions in projections ¶ If you pass a function instead of a string or Ibis expression in any projection context, it will be invoked with the "parent" table as its argument. This can help significantly when [composing complex operations. Consider this SQL: SELECT one , avg ( abs ( the_sum )) AS mad FROM ( SELECT one , three , sum ( two ) AS the_sum FROM my_data GROUP BY 1 , 2 ) t0 GROUP BY 1 This can be written as one chained expression: In [16]: Copied! expr = ( t . group_by ([ 'one' , 'three' ]) . aggregate ( the_sum = t . two . sum ()) . group_by ( 'one' ) . aggregate ( mad = lambda x : x . the_sum . abs () . mean ()) ) expr = ( t.group_by(['one', 'three']) .aggregate(the_sum=t.two.sum()) .group_by('one') .aggregate(mad=lambda x: x.the_sum.abs().mean()) ) Indeed: In [17]: Copied!
